==New Jersey Beach Project 2017== Despite court actions and an election where Margate NJ voters rejected a planned beach replenishment project, in the Summer of 2017, Corp engineers began work creating dunes in Ventnor and Margate City, New Jersey. They made a very big mess, and additionally, beaches which are tested weekly in the summer for bacteria and toxins experienced unprecedented closings due to dangerous levels.<ref>http://www.philly.com/philly/news/new_jersey/margate-in-uproar-about-lake-christie-may-go-to-court-to-halt-dune-work-20170731.html</ref> <ref>http://www.pressofatlanticcity.com/news/top_three/crowds-protest-margate-dunes-over-public-health-concerns/article_d375fcbe-7ace-5a15-856f-326a268c4cbe.html#tncms-source=article-nav-next</ref> [[File:Dune Problems Cause Flooding July 29, 2017.jpg|alt=Margate Dune Flooding|thumb|Trapped Contaminated Water behind Margate Dunes]] On Aug 2, 2017, Margate Commissioners voted to go back to court in order to seek an injunction. They wanted an immediate work stoppage by the NJ DEP & Army Corp of Engineers. Mistakes in building the dunes, caused substantial flooding and contaminated, standing water between the new dune and the bulkheads. [[File:Beach_and_Dune_Work,_Margate_NJ._Aug_2,_2017.jpg|thumb|Building dunes in Margate, NJ.]]
==Calls for Corps reform== Some in Congress feel that reforms are necessary in the way the Corps operates. The Corps has been criticized as being mismanaged and lacking oversight and accountability, especially since Hurricane Katrina and the failure of the [[Flood Control Act of 1965|Army Corps built levees]] in New Orleans.
Senator [[Russ Feingold]] and Senator [[John McCain]] pushed to establish two amendments; one an independent review of Corps projects from planning and design to construction, and a second that would require that Corps projects be ranked in importance based on national priorities. In 2006, they succeeded in adding the peer review of corps projects to the [[Water Resources Development Act of 2007|Water resources development bill]] that was working its way through Congress.<ref name=autogenerated2 />
In August 2007, Senator Feingold himself tried to block passage of the bill because he felt the reforms it contained would not do enough to change the way the Corps does business.[https://web.archive.org/web/20071012232742/http://feingold.senate.gov/] {{quote|After a decade of government and independent reports calling for reforming the corps and pointing out stunning flaws in corps projects and project studies, and after the tragic failures of New Orleans levees during Hurricane Katrina, the American people deserve meaningful reform. How many more flawed projects or wasted dollars will it take before we say enough is enough?|Senator Feingold from the Senate Floor<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2007/09/25/washington/25water.html?_r=1&8br&oref=slogin Feingold blocks reform bill passage because it doesn't go far enough]</ref>}}
Calls for reform go back decades; the Corps' credibility had been challenged as early as the late 1920s. Herbert Hoover, then Secretary of Commerce, declared the [[Great Mississippi Flood of 1927]] as “greatest disaster of peace times in our history”, which covered {{convert|26000|sqmi|km2|sigfig=2}} in seven states. More than 700,000 people were driven from their homes.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://140.194.76.129/publications/eng-pamphlets/ep870-1-29/entire.pdf |title=The Evolution of the Flood Control Act of 1936 |format=PDF |accessdate=26 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110529061103/http://140.194.76.129/publications/eng-pamphlets/ep870-1-29/entire.pdf |archivedate=29 May 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> More recent attempts at reform have been made in the 106th, 107th, 108th, and 109th Congresses.<ref name=autogenerated1 /> But as Senator Feingold indicated by quoting the Times-Picayune:<ref name=autogenerated1 />{{cquote|"Unfortunately, not everyone in Congress is interested in changing the way the corps does business. The McCain-Feingold amendments face opposition and a rival set of measures by the main authors of the water resources bill, Sens. James Inhofe and Kit Bond.... Sham reform won't do anything to restore confidence in the corps, and Congress must do better."}}
On 8 November 2007, the [[Water Resources Development Act of 2007]] became law over President Bush' veto of the bill.
In 2012, President Obama issued [[List of United States federal executive orders 13489 and above|Executive Order 13604]], Improving Performance of Federal Permitting and Review of Infrastructure Projects, to streamline and reduce the time required for review and permitting of infrastructure projects.<ref>[http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/FR-2012-03-28/pdf/2012-7636.pdf Executive Order 13604], Federal Register.</ref> The feasibility study and environmental assessment for the deepening of [[Charleston Harbor]] was the first project to be completed under this new process.<ref>Segrist, Liz. [http://www.charlestonbusiness.com/news/55667-army-corps-chief-rsquo-s-report-signs-off-on-charleston-harbor-deepening-project Army Corps Chief’s Report signs off on Charleston Harbor deepening project]. Charleston Regional Business Journal, September 14, 2015.</ref>
